trust.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: a strong belief in the honesty, goodness etc of someone or something
trust.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: At first there was a lack of trust between them.
an agreement made on the basis of mutual trust (=when people trust each other)
You betrayed your father’s trust (=did something bad even though he trusted you).
You shouldn’t put your trust in a man like that.
trust.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: an organization or group that has control over money that will be used to help someone else
trust.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: an arrangement by which someone has legal control of your money or property, either until you are old enough to use it or to invest  it for you
trust.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: The money your father left you will be held in trust until you are 21.
trust.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: a group of companies that illegally work together to reduce competition and control prices
trust.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to believe that someone is honest or will not do anything bad or wrong
trust.translation[1].definitions[0].note: not trust somebody an inch/not trust somebody as far as you can throw them (=not trust someone at all)
trust.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: He was a good driver and I trusted him implicitly.
Can they be trusted to look after the house?
I didn’t trust myself not to say something rude, so I just kept quiet.
trust.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to be sure that something is correct or right
trust.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: Trust your instincts (=do what you feel is the right thing)!
trust.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: to be sure that something will work properly
trust.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: Not trusting her voice, she shook her head.
You can’t trust the trains to run on time.
He sat down suddenly, as if he didn’t trust his legs to support him.
trust.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: a belief in the honesty or goodness of someone or something
trust.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: The measures are necessary to restore public trust in the futures markets.
He abused his position of trust (=a job with responsibility for making important decisions) and defrauded the institution.
trust.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: to believe that something is true without having any proof
trust.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: I just had to take it on trust that he would deliver the money.
trust.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: an arrangement by which someone has legal control over your money or property until you are old enough to use it
trust.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: The money your father left you will be held in trust until you are 21.
trust.translation[2].definitions[3].defi: an arrangement by which someone has legal control over your money and usually invests it for you, or an organization that does this
trust.translation[2].definitions[3].exam: He put his assets in a variety of trusts.
trust.translation[2].definitions[4].defi: a group of companies that illegally work together to reduce competition and control prices
